reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: Green Energy Business from Agroforestry Woodlots (GRENEBAW)

description.narrative: The project will establish a business company demonstrating 2 national REDD+ strategic option activities to be approved by Uganda shortly that will show a way to curb current high forest destruction and carbon emissions from unsustainable charcoal making p ractices while simultaneously fourfold increase farmers? income generation. A business will be established between FMP and rural small-holder farmers in Buikwe and Kayunga Districts in central Uganda who would invest at least 7 ha of their rainfed farmland in the business. In Eritrea there will be 7 ha from the Hamelmalo Agricultural College production farm in Keren area included in agroforestry type of energy wood plantations with an introduced fast-growing tree species suitable for charcoal making. The en ergy wood should produce annually 10-20 tonnes of energy wood of which 2-5 tonnes of smallest-size wood would be used as commercial fuelwood while the remaining wood will be charcoaled in a substantially improved charcoal kiln (either Sam 1 or Adam retort kiln) which produces over 3 times more charcoal than traditional kilns. The trees will be cut at about 1 m stump height which allows almost normal cash crop cultivation of maize or similar crop in alley corridors between tree rows. As trees are nitrogen-fi xing they will fertilize the farmland and allow 2-3 times higher crop yield than monoculture cultivation. The energy trees will provide annually 2-5 tonnes of leaf fodder which can further be extended by cultivating a small part of farmland with additional fodder crop. The fodder can feed milking cow(s) which can provide commercial milk income (i.e. either fodder or milk is sold). The energy wood plantation will start providing cash income from 2nd year (fuelwood) while charcoal production starts in 3rd or 4th year (depending on 3rd year tree size). Cash crops and fodder/milk can be sold from first year. Additional income can come from the preparation of REDD+ guidelines and training packages to be sold to farmers and authorities in Uganda and Eritrea. FMP w ill act as the facilitator and innovator of the involved farmers and university staff. FMP likely to withdraw after 8-10 years of operations.
